column1: Nauen is a small town in the Havelland district
column3: Germany. It is chiefly known for Nauen Transmitter Station
column4: the world's oldest preserved radio transmitting installation.

column1: Nauen is situated within the Havelland Luch glacial lowland
column2: the heart of the Havelland region north of the Nauen Plateau
column3: about 38 km (24 mi) west of the Berlin city centre (18 km (11 mi) off the Berlin city limits) and 27 km (17 mi) northwest of Potsdam. It is one of Germany's largest municipalities by area
column4: comprising Nauen proper and fourteen surrounding villages
column5: including Ribbeck whose landowners were perpetuated in Theodor Fontane's poem Herr von Ribbeck auf Ribbeck im Havelland.

column1: The settlement of Nowen was first mentioned in an 1186 deed issued by the Bishop of Brandenburg. The citizens received town privileges by the Brandenburg margraves in 1292; a first town hall was built in 1302. The Ascanian margrave Waldemar vested Nauen with market rights in 1317. A Jewish community already existed in medieval times.

column3: Nauen was devastated by Imperial troops led by Field Marshal Count Johann Tserclaes of Tilly. On 27 June 1675
column4: Swedish and Brandenburg troops met at the Battle of Nauen during the Scanian War. Under Prussian rule
column5: Nauen became a garrison town. In 1846 it received access to the Berlin–Hamburg Railway.

column1: Nauen is well known for the location of a transmission site. It was used from 1906 to 1945 for VLF and shortwave. After 1945 the installations were dismantled
column2: but after 1955 the GDR started building up a shortwave transmission center at Nauen. Since 1997 four turnable shortwave transmission aerials have been sited there.
